trans-unit.source: Connecting DocumentDB with Azure Search using indexers | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Connecting DocumentDB with Azure Search using indexers | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to use to Azure Search indexer with DocumentDB as a data source.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to use to Azure Search indexer with DocumentDB as a data source.

trans-unit.source: Connecting DocumentDB with Azure Search using indexers
trans-unit.target: Connecting DocumentDB with Azure Search using indexers

trans-unit.source: If you're looking to implement great search experiences over your DocumentDB data, use Azure Search indexer for DocumentDB!
trans-unit.target: If you're looking to implement great search experiences over your DocumentDB data, use Azure Search indexer for DocumentDB!

trans-unit.source: In this article, we will show you how to integrate Azure DocumentDB with Azure Search without having to write any code to maintain indexing infrastructure!
trans-unit.target: In this article, we will show you how to integrate Azure DocumentDB with Azure Search without having to write any code to maintain indexing infrastructure!

trans-unit.source: To set this up, you have to setup an Azure Search account (you don't need to upgrade to standard search), and then call the Azure Search REST API to create a DocumentDB data source and an indexer for that data source.
trans-unit.target: To set this up, you have to setup an Azure Search account (you don't need to upgrade to standard search), and then call the Azure Search REST API to create a DocumentDB data source and an indexer for that data source.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Azure Search indexer concepts
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Azure Search indexer concepts

trans-unit.source: Azure Search supports the creation and management of data sources (including DocumentDB) and indexers that operate against those data sources.
trans-unit.target: Azure Search supports the creation and management of data sources (including DocumentDB) and indexers that operate against those data sources.

trans-unit.source: A data source specifies what data needs to be indexed, credentials to access the data, and policies to enable Azure Search to efficiently identify changes in the data (such as modified or deleted documents inside your collection).
trans-unit.target: A data source specifies what data needs to be indexed, credentials to access the data, and policies to enable Azure Search to efficiently identify changes in the data (such as modified or deleted documents inside your collection).

trans-unit.source: The data source is defined as an independent resource so that it can be used by multiple indexers.
trans-unit.target: The data source is defined as an independent resource so that it can be used by multiple indexers.

trans-unit.source: An indexer describes how the data flows from your data source into a target search index.
trans-unit.target: An indexer describes how the data flows from your data source into a target search index.

trans-unit.source: You should plan on creating one indexer for every target index and data source combination.
trans-unit.target: You should plan on creating one indexer for every target index and data source combination.

trans-unit.source: While you can have multiple indexers writing into the same index, an indexer can only write into a single index.
trans-unit.target: While you can have multiple indexers writing into the same index, an indexer can only write into a single index.

trans-unit.source: An indexer is used to:
trans-unit.target: An indexer is used to:

trans-unit.source: Perform a one-time copy of the data to populate an index.
trans-unit.target: Perform a one-time copy of the data to populate an index.

trans-unit.source: Sync an index with changes in the data source on a schedule.
trans-unit.target: Sync an index with changes in the data source on a schedule.

trans-unit.source: The schedule is part of the indexer definition.
trans-unit.target: The schedule is part of the indexer definition.

trans-unit.source: Invoke on-demand updates to an index as needed.
trans-unit.target: Invoke on-demand updates to an index as needed.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Create a data source
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Create a data source

trans-unit.source: Issue a HTTP POST request to create a new data source in your Azure Search service, including the following request headers.
trans-unit.target: Issue a HTTP POST request to create a new data source in your Azure Search service, including the following request headers.

trans-unit.source: The api-version is required.
trans-unit.target: The api-version is required.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include 2015-02-28 or a later version.
trans-unit.target: Valid values include 2015-02-28 or a later version.

trans-unit.source: The body of the request contains the data source definition, which should include the following fields:
trans-unit.target: The body of the request contains the data source definition, which should include the following fields:

trans-unit.source: name: The name of the data source.
trans-unit.target: name: The name of the data source.

trans-unit.source: type: Use documentdb.
trans-unit.target: type: Use documentdb.

trans-unit.source: credentials:
trans-unit.target: credentials:

trans-unit.source: connectionString: Required. Specify the connection info to your Azure DocumentDB database in the following format: AccountEndpoint=;AccountKey=;Database=
trans-unit.target: connectionString: Required. Specify the connection info to your Azure DocumentDB database in the following format: AccountEndpoint=;AccountKey=;Database=

trans-unit.source: container:
trans-unit.target: container:

trans-unit.source: name: Required.
trans-unit.target: name: Required.

trans-unit.source: Specify the DocumentDB collection to be indexed.
trans-unit.target: Specify the DocumentDB collection to be indexed.

trans-unit.source: query: Optional.
trans-unit.target: query: Optional.

trans-unit.source: You can specify a query to flatten an arbitrary JSON document into a flat schema that Azure Search can index.
trans-unit.target: You can specify a query to flatten an arbitrary JSON document into a flat schema that Azure Search can index.

trans-unit.source: dataChangeDetectionPolicy: Optional.
trans-unit.target: dataChangeDetectionPolicy: Optional.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Data Change Detection Policy</linkText><title></title></link> below.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Data Change Detection Policy</linkText><title></title></link> below.

trans-unit.source: dataDeletionDetectionPolicy: Optional.
trans-unit.target: dataDeletionDetectionPolicy: Optional.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Data Deletion Detection Policy</linkText><title></title></link> below.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Data Deletion Detection Policy</linkText><title></title></link> below.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Capturing changed documents
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Capturing changed documents

trans-unit.source: The purpose of a data change detection policy is to efficiently identify changed data items.
trans-unit.target: The purpose of a data change detection policy is to efficiently identify changed data items.

trans-unit.source: Currently, the only supported policy is the High Water Mark policy using the _ts last-modified timestamp property provided by DocumentDB - which is specified as follows:
trans-unit.target: Currently, the only supported policy is the High Water Mark policy using the _ts last-modified timestamp property provided by DocumentDB - which is specified as follows:

trans-unit.source: You will also need to add _ts in the projection and WHERE clause for your query.
trans-unit.target: You will also need to add _ts in the projection and WHERE clause for your query.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Capturing deleted documents
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Capturing deleted documents

trans-unit.source: When rows are deleted from the source table, you should delete those rows from the search index as well.
trans-unit.target: When rows are deleted from the source table, you should delete those rows from the search index as well.

trans-unit.source: The purpose of a data deletion detection policy is to efficiently identify deleted data items.
trans-unit.target: The purpose of a data deletion detection policy is to efficiently identify deleted data items.

trans-unit.source: Currently, the only supported policy is the Soft Delete policy (deletion is marked with a flag of some sort), which is specified as follows:
trans-unit.target: Currently, the only supported policy is the Soft Delete policy (deletion is marked with a flag of some sort), which is specified as follows:

trans-unit.source: You will need to include the property in your SELECT clause if you are using a custom projection.
trans-unit.target: You will need to include the property in your SELECT clause if you are using a custom projection.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Request body example
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Request body example

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a data source with a custom query and policy hints:
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a data source with a custom query and policy hints:

trans-unit.source: Response
trans-unit.target: Response

trans-unit.source: You will receive an HTTP 201 Created response if the data source was successfully created.
trans-unit.target: You will receive an HTTP 201 Created response if the data source was successfully created.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Create an index
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Create an index

trans-unit.source: Create a target Azure Search index if you don’t have one already.
trans-unit.target: Create a target Azure Search index if you don’t have one already.

trans-unit.source: You can do this from the <link><linkText>Azure Portal UI</linkText><title></title></link> or by using the <link><linkText>Create Index API</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can do this from the <link><linkText>Azure Portal UI</linkText><title></title></link> or by using the <link><linkText>Create Index API</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that the schema of your target index is compatible with the schema of the source JSON documents or the output of your custom query projection.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that the schema of your target index is compatible with the schema of the source JSON documents or the output of your custom query projection.

trans-unit.source: Figure A: Mapping between JSON Data Types and Azure Search Data Types
trans-unit.target: Figure A: Mapping between JSON Data Types and Azure Search Data Types

trans-unit.source: JSON DATA TYPE
trans-unit.target: JSON DATA TYPE

trans-unit.source: COMPATIBLE TARGET INDEX FIELD TYPES
trans-unit.target: COMPATIBLE TARGET INDEX FIELD TYPES

trans-unit.source: Bool
trans-unit.target: Bool

trans-unit.source: Edm.Boolean, Edm.String
trans-unit.target: Edm.Boolean, Edm.String

trans-unit.source: Numbers that look like integers
trans-unit.target: Numbers that look like integers

trans-unit.source: Edm.Int32, Edm.Int64, Edm.String
trans-unit.target: Edm.Int32, Edm.Int64, Edm.String

trans-unit.source: Numbers that look like floating-points
trans-unit.target: Numbers that look like floating-points

trans-unit.source: Edm.Double, Edm.String
trans-unit.target: Edm.Double, Edm.String

trans-unit.source: String
trans-unit.target: String

trans-unit.source: Edm.String
trans-unit.target: Edm.String

trans-unit.source: Arrays of primitive types e.g. "a", "b", "c"
trans-unit.target: Arrays of primitive types e.g. "a", "b", "c"

trans-unit.source: Collection(Edm.String)
trans-unit.target: Collection(Edm.String)

trans-unit.source: Strings that look like dates
trans-unit.target: Strings that look like dates

trans-unit.source: Edm.DateTimeOffset, Edm.String
trans-unit.target: Edm.DateTimeOffset, Edm.String

trans-unit.source: GeoJSON objects e.g. { "type": "Point", "coordinates": [ long, lat ] }
trans-unit.target: GeoJSON objects e.g. { "type": "Point", "coordinates": [ long, lat ] }

trans-unit.source: Edm.GeographyPoint
trans-unit.target: Edm.GeographyPoint

trans-unit.source: Other JSON objects
trans-unit.target: Other JSON objects

trans-unit.source: N/A
trans-unit.target: N/A

trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Request body example

trans-unit.source: The following example creates an index with an id and description field:
trans-unit.target: The following example creates an index with an id and description field:

trans-unit.source: Response
trans-unit.target: Response

trans-unit.source: You will receive an HTTP 201 Created response if the index was successfully created.
trans-unit.target: You will receive an HTTP 201 Created response if the index was successfully created.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Create an indexer
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Create an indexer

trans-unit.source: You can create a new indexer within an Azure Search service by using an HTTP POST request with the following headers.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new indexer within an Azure Search service by using an HTTP POST request with the following headers.

trans-unit.source: The body of the request contains the indexer definition, which should include the following fields:
trans-unit.target: The body of the request contains the indexer definition, which should include the following fields:

trans-unit.source: name: Required.
trans-unit.target: name: Required.

trans-unit.source: The name of the indexer.
trans-unit.target: The name of the indexer.

trans-unit.source: dataSourceName: Required.
trans-unit.target: dataSourceName: Required.

trans-unit.source: The name of an existing data source.
trans-unit.target: The name of an existing data source.

trans-unit.source: targetIndexName: Required.
trans-unit.target: targetIndexName: Required.

trans-unit.source: The name of an existing index.
trans-unit.target: The name of an existing index.

trans-unit.source: schedule: Optional.
trans-unit.target: schedule: Optional.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Indexing Schedule</linkText><title></title></link> below.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Indexing Schedule</linkText><title></title></link> below.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Running indexers on a schedule
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Running indexers on a schedule

trans-unit.source: An indexer can optionally specify a schedule.
trans-unit.target: An indexer can optionally specify a schedule.

trans-unit.source: If a schedule is present, the indexer will run periodically as per schedule.
trans-unit.target: If a schedule is present, the indexer will run periodically as per schedule.

trans-unit.source: Schedule has the following attributes:
trans-unit.target: Schedule has the following attributes:

trans-unit.source: interval: Required.
trans-unit.target: interval: Required.

trans-unit.source: A duration value that specifies an interval or period for indexer runs.
trans-unit.target: A duration value that specifies an interval or period for indexer runs.

trans-unit.source: The smallest allowed interval is 5 minutes; the longest is one day.
trans-unit.target: The smallest allowed interval is 5 minutes; the longest is one day.

trans-unit.source: It must be formatted as an XSD "dayTimeDuration" value (a restricted subset of an <link><linkText>ISO 8601 duration</linkText><title></title></link> value).
trans-unit.target: It must be formatted as an XSD "dayTimeDuration" value (a restricted subset of an <link><linkText>ISO 8601 duration</linkText><title></title></link> value).

trans-unit.source: The pattern for this is: P(nD)(T(nH)(nM)).
trans-unit.target: The pattern for this is: P(nD)(T(nH)(nM)).

trans-unit.source: Examples: PT15M for every 15 minutes, PT2H for every 2 hours.
trans-unit.target: Examples: PT15M for every 15 minutes, PT2H for every 2 hours.

trans-unit.source: startTime: Required.
trans-unit.target: startTime: Required.

trans-unit.source: An UTC datetime that specifies when the indexer should start running.
trans-unit.target: An UTC datetime that specifies when the indexer should start running.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Request body example
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Request body example

trans-unit.source: The following example creates an indexer that copies data from the collection referenced by the myDocDbDataSource data source to the mySearchIndex index on a schedule that starts on Jan 1, 2015 UTC and runs hourly.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates an indexer that copies data from the collection referenced by the myDocDbDataSource data source to the mySearchIndex index on a schedule that starts on Jan 1, 2015 UTC and runs hourly.

trans-unit.source: Response
trans-unit.target: Response

trans-unit.source: You will receive an HTTP 201 Created response if the indexer was successfully created.
trans-unit.target: You will receive an HTTP 201 Created response if the indexer was successfully created.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 4: Run an indexer
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 4: Run an indexer

trans-unit.source: In addition to running periodically on a schedule, an indexer can also be invoked on demand by issuing the following HTTP POST request:
trans-unit.target: In addition to running periodically on a schedule, an indexer can also be invoked on demand by issuing the following HTTP POST request:

trans-unit.source: Response
trans-unit.target: Response

trans-unit.source: You will receive an HTTP 202 Accepted response if the indexer was successfully invoked.
trans-unit.target: You will receive an HTTP 202 Accepted response if the indexer was successfully invoked.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 5: Get indexer status
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 5: Get indexer status

trans-unit.source: You can issue a HTTP GET request to retrieve the current status and execution history of an indexer:
trans-unit.target: You can issue a HTTP GET request to retrieve the current status and execution history of an indexer:

trans-unit.source: Response
trans-unit.target: Response

trans-unit.source: You will see a HTTP 200 OK response returned along with a response body that contains information about overall indexer health status, the last indexer invocation, as well as the history of recent indexer invocations (if present).
trans-unit.target: You will see a HTTP 200 OK response returned along with a response body that contains information about overall indexer health status, the last indexer invocation, as well as the history of recent indexer invocations (if present).

trans-unit.source: The response should look similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: The response should look similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: Execution history contains up to the 50 most recent completed executions, which are sorted in reverse chronological order (so the latest execution comes first in the response).
trans-unit.target: Execution history contains up to the 50 most recent completed executions, which are sorted in reverse chronological order (so the latest execution comes first in the response).

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Next steps
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Next steps

trans-unit.source: Congratulations!
trans-unit.target: Congratulations!

trans-unit.source: You have just learned how to integrate Azure DocumentDB with Azure Search using the indexer for DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: You have just learned how to integrate Azure DocumentDB with Azure Search using the indexer for DocumentDB.
